example:
A: I think I really frustrated my sister.
B: What did you do this time?
A: Ate her leftovers. Again.
B: You have a death wish.
A: She's not talking to me now.
B: Buy her boba, she'll get over it.
japanese: 妹（いもうと）を困（こま）らせた／イラつかせた
chinese: 气坏了我妹妹 (Qì huài le wǒ mèimei) / 让我妹妹很郁闷 (Ràng wǒ mèimei hěn yùmèn)
spanish: Me tiene frito mi hermana / Puse de los nervios a mi hermana

primary: Something feels off / I'm feeling under the weather
meaning: 어쩐지 이상해 / 몸 상태가 안 좋아
example:
A: You’ve been very quiet all morning. 
B: Something feels off, and I think I'm coming down with something. 
A: Are you feeling under the weather? 
B: Yeah, I’m just feeling really out of sorts today. 
A: You should go home and rest. 
B: I think I will, I’m definitely not feeling 100%.
japanese: なんか変（へん）だ／調子（ちょうし）が悪（わる）い
chinese: 感觉不太对劲 / 身体不太舒服 (Gǎnjué bù tài duìjìn / Shēntǐ bù tài shūfu) / 欠安 (Qiàn'ān)
spanish: Algo no me cuadra / Me siento raro

similar: 2. I’m a bit out of it
example:
A: Sorry I snapped at you earlier. 
B: It’s okay, you seemed a bit stressed. 
A: Honestly, I'm not myself lately with all this work. 
B: I can tell you're a bit off your game. 
A: I just need a long weekend to recharge. 
B: We all get in a fog sometimes, don't worry about it.
japanese: いつもの自分（じぶん）じゃない／本調子（ほんちょうし）じゃない
chinese: 我不在状态 (Wǒ bù zài zhuàngtài) / 我有点反常 (Wǒ yǒudiǎn fǎncháng)
spanish: No soy yo mismo / Ando un poco perdido

primary: Your best bet / Your go-to option
example:
A: Which subway line should I take to Brooklyn? 
B: The L train is your best bet for that area. 
A: Is it usually faster than the bus? 
B: Definitely, it’s the go-to option for commuters. 
A: Thanks, I’ll head to the station now. 
B: It’s your safest bet to avoid the traffic.
japanese: それが一番（いちばん）無難（ぶなん）だ／ベストな選択（せんたく）だ
chinese: 你的最佳选择 / 首选 (Nǐ de zuìjiā xuǎnzé / Shǒuxuǎn) / 万全之策 (Wànquánzhīcè)
spanish: Tu mejor opción / Lo más seguro es...

primary: I'm a little pressed for time / Clock is ticking / Time is running out
meaning: 시간이 좀 촉박해 / 시간이 다 되어 가
example:
A: Can we talk about the budget for five minutes? 
B: Make it quick, I'm a little pressed for time. 
A: I just need your signature on this form. 
B: The clock is ticking on my next meeting. 
A: I understand, it’ll only take a second. 
B: Good, because time is running out before I have to leave.
japanese: 時間（じかん）がない／急（いそ）いでいる
chinese: 时间紧迫 (Shíjiān jǐnpò) / 没时间了 (Méi shíjiān le)
spanish: Ando corto de tiempo / El reloj corre

example:
A: How is the new management role going? 
B: To be honest, I think I can't hack it. 
A: Is it the workload or the people? 
B: Everything. I’m just totally out of my depth. 
A: Give it some time before you give up. 
B: I’m trying, but I’ve never felt this overwhelmed.
japanese: やってられない／手（て）に負（お）えない
chinese: 驾驭不了 (Jiàyù bùliǎo) / 吃不消 (Chībuxiāo)
spanish: No me da el cuero / No puedo con esto

primary: It's going to sound corny / It might sound cheesy
example:
A: Why did you get me these flowers? 
B: It's going to sound corny, but I just wanted to see you smile. 
A: That’s actually really sweet. 
B: I know it might sound cheesy, but I mean it. 
A: Stop, you're making me blush. 
B: I guess I’m just feeling a bit sentimental today.
japanese: 臭（くさ）いセリフだけど／陳腐（ちんぷ）に聞（き）こえるかもしれないけど
chinese: 听起来可能有点俗气 (Tīng qǐlái kěnéng yǒudiǎn súqì) / 有点煽情 (Yǒudiǎn shānqíng)
spanish: Va a sonar cursi / Sonará empalagoso

primary: It's not too shabby / Not that bad
example:
A: How do you like the new apartment? 
B: It's not too shabby for the price. 
A: The neighborhood seems not that bad either. 
B: It’s actually a pretty decent area. 
A: And the view from the balcony? 
B: It’s respectable, I can see the park from here.
japanese: 悪（わる）くないね／なかなかいいじゃん
chinese: 还凑合吧 (Hái còuhé ba) / 挺像那么回事的 (Tǐng xiàng nàme huí shì de)
spanish: No está nada mal / Se deja ver

example:
A: You look like you need a vacation. 
B: I’m thinking of heading to a spa for some pampering. 
A: You definitely deserve a self-care day. 
B: I just want to spoil myself with a massage. 
A: Go for it, it’s much-needed relaxation time. 
B: I’m booking the luxury break right now.
japanese: スパで癒（いや）されたい／自分（じぶん）へのご褒美（ほうび）
chinese: 去水疗放松一下 (Qù shuǐliáo fàngsōng yīxià) / 享受一下按摩 (Xiǎngshòu yīxià ànmó)
spanish: Un spa para que me mimen / Un día de relax

example:
A: Why did you tell him about the surprise party? 
B: I’m so sorry, it just slipped out! 
A: We’ve been planning this for weeks! 
B: It was a total slip of the tongue, I swear. 
A: You always let things slip when you're excited. 
B: I know, I just spoke without thinking.
japanese: つい口（くち）が滑（すべ）った
chinese: 顺口就说出来了 (Shùnkǒu jiù shuō chūlái le) / 嘴快了 (Zuǐ kuài le)
spanish: Se me escapó / Se me salió sin querer

example:
A: How was your last day at the office? 
B: It was very bitter sweet, to be honest. 
A: I bet you'll miss the team. 
B: Yeah, I have mixed feelings about moving on. 
A: It’s a poignant moment in your career. 
B: It is, I’m happy for the new start but wistful about leaving.
japanese: 嬉（うれ）しくもあり寂（さび）しくもある／複雑（ふくざつ）な気分（きぶん）
chinese: 苦乐参半 (Kǔlè cānbàn) / 悲喜交加 (Bēixǐ jiāojiā)
spanish: Agridulce / Una de cal y una de arena

primary: Don’t flatter yourself / Don’t give yourself too much credit
example:
A: I’m pretty sure she was staring at me all night. 
B: Don’t flatter yourself, she was looking at the exit. 
A: Hey, I’m a catch! 
B: Don’t give yourself too much credit, man. 
A: You're just jealous of my looks. 
B: Seriously, come back to earth and eat your pizza.
japanese: 自意識（じいしき）過剰（かじょう）だよ／調子（ちょうし）に乗（の）るな
chinese: 别往自己脸上贴金 (Bié wǎng zìjǐ liǎn shàng tiējīn) / 别臭美了 (Bié chòuměi le)
spanish: No te creas tanto / Bájale los humos

primary: Stop pestering me / Enough with this / Stop nagging me
example:
A: Did you finish the report? Did you? 
B: Stop pestering me, I told you I'll do it by 5. 
A: I just need to make sure it’s done. 
B: Enough with this, I’m working on it right now. 
A: I'm only asking because it's important. 
B: Stop nagging me and get off my back for a bit.
japanese: しつこくしないで／うるさく言（い）わないで
chinese: 别烦我了 (Bié fán wǒ le) / 别没完没了的 (Bié méiwánméiliǎo de)
spanish: Deja de dar la lata / No me agobies

example:
A: Is it okay if I eat the last slice of cake? 
B: Knock yourself out, I’m full anyway. 
A: Are you sure you don't want it later? 
B: Suit yourself, if you want it, take it. 
A: Thanks, I’ve been craving it all day. 
B: Be my guest, I’m done with sweets for now.
japanese: 好（す）きにしなよ／ご自由（じゆう）に
chinese: 请便吧 / 随你便 (Qǐngbiàn ba / Suí nǐ biàn) / 你看着办吧 (Nǐ kànzhe bàn ba)
spanish: Házte el gusto / Tú mismo

primary: Run it by you / Touch base with you
example:
A: I have a new idea for the marketing campaign. 
B: Great, run it by me during our meeting. 
A: I also wanted to touch base with you on the budget. 
B: Let's check in on that after lunch. 
A: I need to get your take on the final design too. 
B: Perfect, loop me in on the email chain.
japanese: 相談（そうだん）する／確認（かくにん）をとる
chinese: 跟你商量一下 (Gēn nǐ shāngliang yīxià) / 听听你的意见 (Tīngting nǐ de yìjiàn)
spanish: Consultártelo / Comentártelo

similar: 1. With my personal stuff going on
2. I've got a lot on my plate
3. Life's been a bit much lately
example:
A: I haven't seen you at the gym lately.
B: Sorry, I've been busy with my personal stuff.
A: Is everything okay at home?
B: Yeah, just got a lot on my plate right now.
A: I get it, life can be a bit much sometimes.
B: Thanks for understanding, I'll be back soon.
japanese: 取（と）り込（こ）んでいる／忙（いそが）しい
chinese: 我最近一直挺忙的 (Wǒ zuìjìn yīzhí tǐng máng de) / 俗事缠身 (Súshì chánshēn)
spanish: He estado liado / Ando a mil

example:
A: I think I broke my toe hitting the desk!
B: Let me see. It’s just a tiny bruise.
A: It hurts so much, I might need a doctor.
B: You will live, stop overreacting.
A: You're so heartless sometimes.
B: Just put some ice on it and keep moving.
japanese: 死（し）にゃしないよ／大丈夫（だいじょうぶ）だって
chinese: 你死不了 (Nǐ sǐ bùliǎo) / 这点小事难不倒你 (Zhè diǎn xiǎoshì nán bù dǎo nǐ)
spanish: No te vas a morir / Sobrevivirás

example:
A: I'm so nervous about starting this new job.
B: Don't worry, I've been here for five years.
A: Everything seems so complicated in New York.
B: I’ll take you under my wing and show you around.
A: That would be a huge help, thank you.
B: Just stay close and ask anything you need.
japanese: 面倒（めんどう）を見（み）る／世話（せわ）をする
chinese: 关照 (Guānzhào) / 提携 (Tíxié)
spanish: Tomar bajo el ala / Apadrinar

example:
A: Did you hear? The meeting was canceled.
B: What? I traveled 두 hours into the city!
A: I know, the boss had an emergency.
B: So all this preparation was for nothing?
A: Pretty much. We'll reschedule for next week.
B: I'm going to grab a drink; I'm exhausted.
japanese: 無駄（むだ）だった／骨折（ほねお）り損（ぞん）
chinese: 白忙活了 (Bái mánghuo le) / 徒劳无功 (Túláowúgōng)
spanish: Para nada / En balde

similar: I’ll make it up to you
example:
A: I covered your shift yesterday when you were sick.
B: Oh man, thank you so much for that.
A: No problem, I knew you weren't feeling well.
B: I really owe you one, seriously.
A: Just help me out next time I need a break.
B: You got it. I'll buy you coffee tomorrow.
japanese: 一（ひと）つ借（か）りね／恩（おん）に着（き）るよ
chinese: 欠你一个人情 (Qiàn nǐ yīgè rénqíng) / 下次补偿你 (Xiàcì bǔcháng nǐ)
spanish: Te debo una / Estoy en deuda

example:
A: Did you see how Mark and Jen were talking?
B: Yeah, there's definitely something going on between them.
A: I thought they were just coworkers.
B: No way, the chemistry is too obvious.
A: I hope it doesn't make things awkward at work.
B: As long as they keep it professional, we're good.
japanese: 何（なに）かあるね（恋愛（れんあい）関係（かんけい））／怪（あや）しいね
chinese: 关系不一般 (Guānxì bù yībān) / 眉来眼去 (Méiláiyǎnqù)
spanish: Hay rollo entre ellos / Ahí hay tema

example:
A: We haven't spoken properly since the argument.
B: I know, it's been feeling really tense lately.
A: Can we sit down and clear the air?
B: I'd like that. I hate this awkwardness.
A: I'm sorry for what I said that night.
B: Thanks, I'm sorry for my reaction too.
japanese: わだかまりを解（と）く／誤解（ごかい）を晴（は）らす
chinese: 消除误会 (Xiāochú wùhuì) / 把话摊开说 (Bǎ huà tānkāi shuō)
spanish: Aclarar las cosas / Limpiar el ambiente

example:
A: You should come with us to the Hamptons!
B: I don't want to get in the way of your family time.
A: Nonsense, the more the merrier!
B: Are you sure your parents won't mind?
A: They actually asked if you were coming.
B: Okay then, I'll start packing my bags.
japanese: 邪魔（じゃま）をする
chinese: 妨碍 (Fáng'ài) / 碍事 (Àishì)
spanish: Estorbar / Meterse en medio

example:
A: Everyone in the office seems so on edge today.
B: It's because the quarterly deadline is tomorrow.
A: I noticed the boss is extra grumpy too.
B: Yeah, don't go in there unless it's an emergency.
A: I'll just stay at my desk and keep my head down.
B: Good idea, let's just survive until Friday.
japanese: ピリピリしている／気（き）が立（た）っている
chinese: 神经紧绷 (Shénjīng jǐnbēng) / 处于崩溃边缘 (Chǔyú bēngkuì biānyuán)
spanish: Con los nervios de punta / Inquieto

example:
A: Man! The subway is delayed again!
B: This is the third time this week.
A: We're going to be so late for the show.
B: Maybe we should just grab an Uber.
A: Look at the traffic, it's not any faster.
B: You're right. NYC transit is a nightmare today.
japanese: マジかよ／なんてこった
chinese: 哎呀! (Āiyā!) / 天哪! (Tiān nǎ!)
spanish: ¡Tío! / ¡Macho!

example:
A: It's finally warm enough to walk through Central Park.
B: I know, spring is definitely in the air.
A: Everyone looks so much happier today.
B: No more heavy coats and gray skies.
A: Let's grab some iced coffee and sit outside.
B: Perfect. I've been waiting months for this.
japanese: 春（はる）めいてきた／春（はる）の予感（よかん）
chinese: 春意盎然 (Chūnyì àngrán) / 春天的气息 (Chūntiān de qìxī)
spanish: Ya huele a primavera / La primavera está en el aire

example:
A: I heard the rent for that studio is $5,000.
B: That's crazy! It's barely 400 square feet.
A: Welcome to Manhattan, I guess.
B: I'd rather live in a tent in Jersey.
A: Well, somebody's clearly paying for it.
B: People have too much money to burn.
japanese: ヤバいね／信（しん）じられない
chinese: 太离谱了 (Tài lípǔ le) / 简直疯了 (Jiǎnzhí fēng le)
spanish: Es una locura / Qué fuerte

example:
A: Did you see the news? Google is closing down!
B: Wait, what? Are you serious?
A: April Fools'! I totally got you.
B: Oh my god, my heart actually stopped.
A: You should have seen your face.
B: I'm never believing anything you say today.
japanese: エイプリルフールだよ／嘘（うそ）だよ
chinese: 万愚节玩笑 (Wànyújié wánxiào) / 愚人节快乐 (Yúrénjié kuàilè)
spanish: ¡Inocente! / Día de los Inocentes

example:
A: I can't believe she talked to the manager behind my back.
B: That's so cold. I thought you guys were friends.
A: Me too, but I guess she wanted that promotion.
B: You need to be careful who you trust in this city.
A: Lesson learned. I'm keeping my distance now.
B: Good. Don't let her get to you.
japanese: 影（かげ）でこそこそと／隠（かく）れて
chinese: 背地里 (Bèidìlǐ) / 背着人 (Bèizhe rén)
spanish: A mis espaldas / Por la espalda

example:
A: I'm heading home to visit my family this weekend.
B: Oh, that's nice! Say hi to your mom for me.
A: Will do! She'll be happy to hear from you.
B: Tell her I'll visit her next time I'm in town.
A: She'd love that. Have a great weekend!
B: Thanks, you too. Travel safe.
japanese: 〜によろしく言（い）っておいて
chinese: 代我向~问好 (Dài wǒ xiàng ~ wènhǎo) / 问个好 (Wèn gè hǎo)
spanish: Salúdame a ~ / Dale recuerdos a ~

meaning: 상처 주고 싶지 않지만 (기분 나쁘게 듣지 마)
example:
A: No offense, but that tie doesn't really match the suit.
B: Really? I thought the red looked good with gray.
A: It's a bit too bright for a formal interview.
B: I appreciate the honesty. I'll go change it.
A: Better safe than sorry when you're job hunting.
B: True. Thanks for looking out for me.
japanese: 悪気（わるぎ）はないんだけど
chinese: 别介意 (Bié jièyì) / 冒犯了 (Màofàn le)
spanish: Sin ofender / No te lo tomes a mal

example:
A: First you go left, then two blocks down, then right.
B: Wait, slow down a bit.
A: It's just past the deli on the corner. Follow me?
B: Okay, I think I've got it now.
A: Good, because I'm not repeating it a third time.
B: Don't worry, I'll find my way.
japanese: ついて来（き）てる？（話（はなし）についてきてる？）
chinese: 明白我的意思吗? (Míngbai wǒ de yìsi ma?) / 跟得上吗 (Gēn de shàng ma)
spanish: ¿Me sigues? / ¿Me explico?

example:
A: I'm so stressed about this presentation!
B: Dude, you need to chill out. You've prepared enough.
A: What if I forget everything on stage?
B: You won't. Just take a deep breath.
A: Maybe we should grab a beer after work.
B: Definitely. Let's just chill out at that new bar.
japanese: 落（お）ち着（つ）けよ／リラックスしろよ
chinese: 放松点儿 (Fàngsōng diǎnr) / 别紧张 (Bié jǐnzhāng)
spanish: Relájate / Bájale un cambio

example:
A: NYU tuition is absolutely insane.
B: Tell me about it. It's robbery.
A: How do people afford this?
B: Loans until we die, basically.
A: Worth it for the degree though?
B: Ask me when I'm paying it off.
japanese: 学費（がくひ）／授業（じゅぎょう）料（りょう）
chinese: 学费 (Xuéfèi) / 授课费 (Shòukèfèi)
spanish: Matrícula / Lo que cuesta la carrera

example:
A: How often do you go to the gym?
B: I try to go every other day.
A: That's quite a lot! I can barely go once a week.
B: It's the only way I can stay sane in this city.
A: Maybe I should start a routine like that.
B: You're welcome to join me on Wednesdays.
japanese: 一日（いちにち）おきに／二日（ふつか）に一回（いっかい）
chinese: 每隔一天 (Měi gé yītiān) / 隔三差五 (Gésānchàwǔ)
spanish: Un día sí y uno no / Día por medio

example:
A: Did you see him take that extra stapler home?
B: Yeah, but I'm not going to tell on him.
A: Why not? It's technically stealing.
B: It's just a stapler, don't be a snitch.
A: I guess you're right. Not my business.
B: Exactly. Let's just focus on our own work.
japanese: 言（い）いつける／チクる
chinese: 打小报告 (Dǎ xiǎobàogào) / 告发 (Gàofā)
spanish: Chivarse / Acusar

example:
A: I stayed at the office until 2 AM last night.
B: Don't overdo it, man. You'll get sick.
A: I just really wanted to finish this project.
B: Health is more important than a deadline.
A: I'll take it easy tonight, I promise.
B: Good. Go home early and get some sleep.
japanese: やり過（す）ぎる／無理（むり）をする
chinese: 做过头了 (Zuò guòtóu le) / 操劳过度 (Cāoláoguòdù)
spanish: Pasarse / Exagerar

example:
A: Why aren't you talking to Sarah?
B: I have a bit of a beef with her lately.
A: What happened? You guys were so close.
B: She took credit for my idea in the meeting.
A: Wow, I can see why you're upset.
B: Yeah, I'm not in a hurry to forgive her.
japanese: 不満（ふまん）がある／文句（もんく）がある
chinese: 跟某人有矛盾 (Gēn mǒurén yǒu máodùn) / 有过节 (Yǒu guòjié)
spanish: Tener bronca con / Tener problemas con

example:
A: How's the freelance life?
B: It's tough, just getting by.
A: NYC is expensive for that.
B: Yeah, barely making rent some months.
A: Hang in there, it'll pick up.
B: Hoping for a big gig soon.
japanese: なんとかやっていく／食（く）いつなぐ
chinese: 勉强糊口 (Miǎnqiǎng húkǒu) / 过得去 (Guò de qù)
spanish: Ir tirando / Sobrevivir

example:
A: Everyone in the office chipped in for your gift.
B: Oh my god, I'm so touched! Thank you.
A: We wanted to show how much we appreciate you.
B: This is the nicest thing anyone's ever done.
A: You deserve it for all your hard work.
B: I don't even know what to say. I'm speechless.
japanese: 感動（かんどう）した／ジーンときた
chinese: 受感动 (Shòu gǎndòng) / 很有感触 (Hěn yǒu gǎnchù)
spanish: Conmovido / Emocionado

example:
A: This steak is so buttery.
B: Right? It just falls apart.
A: Best thing I've ate all year.
B: The texture is unreal.
A: Worth every penny.
B: Totally. I'm dreaming about this later.
japanese: 濃厚（のうこう）な／口（くち）どけの良（よ）い
chinese: 油脂感丰富的 (Yóuzhīgǎn fēngfù de) / 顺滑如丝 (Shùnhuárúsī)
spanish: Mantecoso / Suave como la mantequilla

example:
A: Did you enjoy the movie last night?
B: Honestly, I dozed off halfway through.
A: Was it that boring?
B: No, I was just exhausted from work.
A: I noticed you were quiet during the climax.
B: Yeah, I woke up when the credits started.
japanese: うたた寝（ね）する／寝（ね）落（お）ちする
chinese: 打盹儿 (Dǎdǔnr) / 睡着了 (Shuìzháo le)
spanish: Quedarse frito / Dar una cabezada

similar: By the skin of one's teeth
example:
A: That yellow cab almost clipped your bike!
B: Phew, that was a really close call.
A: You need to be more careful in Midtown traffic.
B: I didn't see him turning without a signal.
A: Glad you're okay. That could've been bad.
B: My heart is still racing. Let's pull over.
japanese: 危（あぶ）なかった／間一髪（かんいっぱつ）
chinese: 侥幸脱险 (Jiǎoxìng tuōxiǎn) / 虚惊一场 (Xūjīng yīchǎng)
spanish: Por los pelos / Casi no la cuento

example:
A: I love the fit of this shirt.
B: It looks great on you.
A: Do you think they have it in another color?
B: I saw some blue ones on the other rack.
A: Let's go check. I'm not a big fan of yellow.
B: Blue would definitely suit you better.
japanese: 色違（いろちが）い
chinese: 换个颜色 (Huàngè yánsè) / 同款不同色 (Tóngkuǎn bùtóng sè)
spanish: En otro color / De otro tono

example:
A: My car broke down for the third time this month.
B: Man, I think you bought a total lemon.
A: I shouldn't have trusted that shady dealer.
B: You should try to get your money back.
A: He's not answering any of my calls.
B: That's rough. You might need a lawyer.
japanese: 欠陥（けっかん）品（ひん）／ポンコツ
chinese: 废品 (Fèipǐn) / 蹩脚货 (Biéjiǎohuò)
spanish: Cacharro / Salió malo

example:
A: I can't finish this pizza. It's too huge.
B: Should we ask for a to-go box?
A: Yeah, I'll have it for breakfast tomorrow.
B: Excuse me, can we get a container here?
A: New York portions are always so massive.
B: I'm not complaining! More for later.
japanese: 持（も）ち帰（かえ）り用（よう）の箱（はこ）
chinese: 打包盒 (Dǎbāohé) / 打包袋 (Dǎbāodài)
spanish: Para llevar / Una cajita

example:
A: He tried to blame the delay on the intern.
B: And what did the boss say?
A: She was not having it. She knew it was his fault.
B: Good for her. He always avoids responsibility.
A: Yeah, she made him stay late to fix it.
B: About time someone stood up to him.
japanese: 許（ゆる）さない／受（う）け入（い）れない
chinese: 不买账 (Bù mǎizhàng) / 不接受这一套 (Bù jiēshòu zhè yī tào)
spanish: No tragar con eso / No estar por la labor

example:
A: I was trying to explain my side of the story.
B: But he just kept cutting me off!
A: That's so rude. Why wouldn't he listen?
B: He thinks he's always the smartest in the room.
A: You should tell him it's disrespectful.
B: I tried, but he cut me off again!
japanese: 遮（さえぎ）る／割（わ）り込（こ）む
chinese: 打断别人讲话 (Dǎduàn biérén jiǎnghuà) / 拦腰斩断 (Lányāozhǎnduàn)
spanish: Cortar el rollo / Interrumpir

primary: That's just the way it is
example:
A: I can't believe they increased the subway fare again.
B: That's just the way it is in this city.
A: Everything is getting so expensive lately.
B: You just have to adapt or move out.
A: I guess there's no point in complaining.
B: Exactly. Let's just focus on making more money.
japanese: 世（よ）の中（なか）そんなもんだ／仕方（しかた）ない
chinese: 事实就是这样 (Shìshí jiùshì zhèyàng) / 无可奈何 (Wúkěnàihé)
spanish: Es lo que hay / Así son las cosas

example:
A: Um, I have something I need to tell you...
B: Just spit it out already! You're making me nervous.
A: I accidentally shrank your favorite sweater.
B: Oh... is that all? I thought it was something bad.
A: Are you mad? I feel terrible about it.
B: It's fine, it was getting old anyway.
japanese: はっきり言（い）えよ／白状（はくじょう）しろよ
chinese: 直说吧 (Zhíshuō ba) / 别吞吞吐吐的 (Bié tūntūntǔtǔ de)
spanish: ¡Suéltalo ya! / Desembucha

example:
A: I didn't know your grandpa passed away.
B: Yeah, last month. He was cremated.
A: That must have been hard.
B: It was, but the service was nice.
A: Where are his ashes?
B: We scattered them at his favorite beach.
japanese: 亡（な）くなって火葬（かそう）された
chinese: 去世并火化了 (Qùshì bìng huǒhuà le) / 走了，已经火葬了 (Zǒu le, yǐjīng huǒzàng le)
spanish: Falleció y lo incineraron / Murió y fue cremado

example:
A: You seem a bit down lately. Is everything okay?
B: I think I'm just getting the fall blues.
A: Is it the shorter days and the cold?
B: Yeah, I always get like this when summer ends.
A: Maybe we should go for a hike upstate.
B: That sounds nice. The colors might help.
japanese: 秋（あき）の憂鬱（ゆううつ）／センチメンタルになる
chinese: 秋愁 (Qiūchóu) / 悲秋 (Bēiqiū)
spanish: Depresión otoñal / Bajón de otoño

example:
A: Is our table ready yet? We've been waiting 20 minutes.
B: Just sit tight, the previous party is just leaving.
A: We're really hungry, can we sit at the bar?
B: It'll just be another minute, I promise.
A: Okay, fine. But please hurry it up.
B: Thank you for your patience. I'll call you soon.
japanese: じっとしてて／動（うご）かないで
chinese: 坐稳了 (Zuò wěn le) / 别乱动，等一下 (Bié luàndòng, děng yīxià)
spanish: Espera un momento / No te muevas

example:
A: What have you been up to lately?
B: Actually, I'm between jobs at the moment.
A: Oh, I'm sorry to hear that. What happened?
B: My company downsized, but I'm looking for something better.
A: Let me know if you need any referrals.
B: Thanks, I really appreciate the support.
japanese: 求職（きゅうしょく）中（ちゅう）／今（いま）は働（はたら）いてない
chinese: 空窗期 (Kōngchuāngqī) / 在找工作呢 (Zài zhǎo gōngzuò ne)
spanish: En paro / Buscando curro

example:
A: I know I lost the game, you don't have to rub it in.
B: I'm not rubbing it in! I'm just celebrating my win.
A: You've mentioned the score five times already.
B: Okay, okay. I'll stop. You played well too.
A: Thanks. Let's just talk about something else.
B: Deal. Want to grab some burgers?
japanese: 嫌味（いやみ）を言（い）う／傷口（きずぐち）に塩（しお）を塗（ぬ）る
chinese: 揭伤疤 (Jiē shāngbā) / 往伤口上撒盐 (Wǎng shāngkǒu shàng sā yán)
spanish: Restregarlo / Echar sal en la herida

example:
A: How is the soup? It looks a bit thin.
B: To be honest, it's a little bland.
A: Maybe it needs more salt or some pepper?
B: Yeah, it definitely needs some seasoning.
A: I'll go grab the spice rack for you.
B: Thanks. This place is usually better than this.
japanese: 味気（あじけ）ない／パンチがない
chinese: 淡而无味 (Dàn ér wúwèi) / 没滋味 (Méi zīwèi)
spanish: Soso / Desabrido

example:
A: I told them I was a famous actor in Korea.
B: And did they actually believe you?
A: They totally ate it up! They even asked for an autograph.
B: No way! You're such a good liar.
A: I guess I have a convincing face.
B: I'm definitely not letting you borrow money from me.
japanese: 鵜呑（うの）みにする／真（ま）に受（う）ける
chinese: 全信了 (Quán xìn le) / 照单全收 (Zhàodānquánshōu)
spanish: Tragárselo todo / Creérselo todo

example:
A: I can't believe Christmas is almost here.
B: I know, it's just around the corner!
A: Have you finished all your shopping yet?
B: Not even close. I'm so behind this year.
A: We should go to the mall this weekend.
B: Sounds like a plan. I need a lot of gifts.
japanese: すぐそこまで来（き）ている／もうすぐだ
chinese: 近在咫尺 (Jìn zài zhǐchǐ) / 就在眼前 (Jiù zài yǎnqián)
spanish: A la vuelta de la esquina / Ya mismo llega

example:
A: Are you excited about the move to Brooklyn?
B: Somewhat. I'm also a bit worried about the commute.
A: It's not that bad if you're near the L train.
B: I hope so. The apartment is much nicer though.
A: That's a huge plus! You'll love the area.
B: Yeah, I'm looking forward to the new cafes.
japanese: ある程度（ていど）は／多少（たしょう）は
chinese: 多少有一点 (Duōshǎo yǒu yīdiǎn) / 某种程度上 (Mǒu zhǒng chéngdù shàng)
spanish: Algo / Más o menos

example:
A: My parents do so much for me, I feel bad.
B: It's easy to take them for granted sometimes.
A: I should really show them more appreciation.
B: Why don't you take them out for dinner?
A: That's a great idea. I'll call them tonight.
B: They'll really appreciate the gesture.
japanese: 当（あ）たり前（まえ）だと思（おも）う／感謝（かんしゃ）を忘（わす）れる
chinese: 习以为常 (Xíyǐwéicháng) / 觉得理所当然 (Juéde lǐsuǒdāngrán)
spanish: Dar por sentado / No valorar

example:
A: Is Mark still planning to move to California?
B: Yeah, he's leaving for good this time.
A: I thought he was just going for a few months.
B: No, he sold his car and everything.
A: Wow, we're really going to miss him.
B: I know. New York won't be the same without him.
japanese: 永久（えいきゅう）に／これを最後（さいご）に
chinese: 彻底 (Chèdǐ) / 永远地 (Yǒngyuǎn de)
spanish: Para siempre / Definitivamente

example:
A: He didn't invite me to his birthday party.
B: Don't take it personally, it was a small gathering.
A: But he invited everyone else in the office!
B: Maybe he just forgot? You should ask him.
A: No way, I'm too hurt to talk to him.
B: You're overthinking it. I'm sure it was an accident.
japanese: 自分（じぶん）への当（あ）てつけだと思（おも）う／真（ま）に受（う）けて傷（きず）つく
chinese: 别往心里去 (Bié wǎng xīnlǐ qù) / 别计较 (Bié jìjiào)
spanish: Tomárselo a pecho / Sentirse aludido

primary: Put it off until the last minute
example:
A: Have you started your tax return yet?
B: No, I always put it off until the last minute.
A: You know the deadline is in two days, right?
B: I work better under pressure, I guess.
A: You're going to be so stressed on Wednesday.
B: I'm already stressed, but I'll get it done.
japanese: ギリギリまで先延（さきの）ばしにする
chinese: 拖到最后一刻 (Tuō dào zuìhòu yīkè) / 临阵磨枪 (Línzhènmóqiāng)
spanish: Dejarlo para el último momento / Procrastinar hasta el final

example:
A: Why did you break up with your boyfriend?
B: He was getting way too clingy lately.
A: Like, he wanted to be with you 24/7?
B: Exactly. I couldn't even go to the gym alone.
A: That sounds exhausting. You need your space.
B: Yeah, I feel much lighter now that I'm single.
japanese: べったりする／依存（いぞん）する
chinese: 粘人 (Niánrén) / 腻歪 (Nìwai)
spanish: Pegajoso / Empalagoso

meaning: 하나도 신경 안 써 (완전 관심 없어)
example:
A: Did you hear what they're saying about you?
B: Honestly, I couldn't care less.
A: But it's spreading all over the office.
B: People in this city always love to gossip.
A: Aren't you going to defend yourself?
B: No, I have better things to do with my time.
japanese: 全（まった）く興味（きょうみ）がない／どうでもいい
chinese: 毫不在乎 (Háobù zàihu) / 关我屁事 (Guān wǒ pì shì)
spanish: Me importa un pimiento / Me da igual

meaning: 말 꺼내서 재수 없게 하지 마
example:
A: We're definitely going to win this.
B: Shh! Don't jinx it!
A: What? We're up by ten points.
B: Anything can happen in the last minute.
A: You're too superstitious.
B: Just knock on wood, please.
japanese: 不吉（ふきつ）なこと言（い）わないで／フラグ立（た）てないで
chinese: 别乌鸦嘴 (Bié wūyāzuǐ) / 别说不吉利的 (Bié shuō bù jílì de)
spanish: No lo gafes / No llames al mal tiempo

example:
A: And then he said, and then I said...
B: Dude, stop yapping.
A: I'm just telling a story!
B: You've been talking for an hour.
A: Fine, I'll be quiet.
B: Thank you. My ears are bleeding.
japanese: 無駄口（むだぐち）を叩（たた）くな／黙（だま）って
chinese: 别嘚嘚了 (Bié dēde le) / 闭嘴 (Bìzuǐ)
spanish: Cierra el pico / Deja de parlotear

example:
A: How's the new apartment?
B: It checks all the boxes.
A: Washer dryer in unit?
B: Yes, and a dishwasher.
A: That's a unicorn in NYC.
B: I know, I felt so lucky.
japanese: 条件（じょうけん）を全（すべ）て満（み）たす／完璧（かんぺき）だ
chinese: 符合所有要求 (Fúhé suǒyǒu yāoqiú) / 面面俱到 (Miànmiàn jùdào)
spanish: Cumple con todo / Lo tiene todo

primary: put it down before I forget
example:
A: That's a great idea for the app.
B: Make sure you put it down before you forget.
A: I'll remember it.
B: No you won't, write it in your notes.
A: Okay, grabbing my phone.
B: Good. Million dollar idea right there.
japanese: 忘（わす）れないうちに書（か）き留（と）める
chinese: 随手记下来 (Suíshǒu jì xiàlái) / 趁还没忘赶紧写下来 (Chèn hái méi wàng gǎnjǐn xiě xiàlái)
spanish: Apúntalo antes de que se me olvide / Anótalo ya

example:
A: How is he so nonchalant about the exam?
B: He probably studied for weeks.
A: He acts like he doesn't care.
B: It's just a front.
A: I'm over here hyperventilating.
B: Try to be more like him, chill.
japanese: 無頓着（むとんちゃく）な／平然（へいぜん）とした
chinese: 若无其事的 (Ruòwúqíshì de) / 淡定的 (Dàndìng de)
spanish: Despreocupado / Como si nada

example:
A: This vacation has been unreal.
B: I don't want to go back to work.
A: Can we just live here?
B: If we win the lottery, maybe.
A: The sunset is perfect.
B: Truly unreal. Adjusting to reality will suck.
japanese: 夢（ゆめ）みたいだった／最高（さいこう）だった
chinese: 太不真实了 (Tài bù zhēnshí le) / 简直像做梦一样 (Jiǎnzhí xiàng zuòmèng yīyàng)
spanish: Ha sido increíble / Parece mentira

example:
A: You look like a zombie.
B: Pulling all-nighters for finals.
A: You need sleep, bro.
B: No time, too much to study.
A: Coffee isn't a meal replacement.
B: It is this week.
japanese: 徹夜（てつや）する
chinese: 熬通宵 (Áo tōngxiāo) / 开夜车 (Kāiyèchē)
spanish: Pasar la noche en vela / Quemarse las pestañas

example:
A: Did you see how he looked at you?
B: It totally made my heart flutter.
A: You guys are crushing hard.
B: I think I really like him.
A: Ask him out then!
B: Maybe next time, I'm too shy.
japanese: ときめく／胸（むね）キュンする
chinese: 心动 (Xīndòng) / 小鹿乱撞 (Xiǎolù luànzhuàng)
spanish: Hacer vibrar el corazón / Acelerar el pulso

example:
A: He liked my story, does he love me?
B: Girl, are you delusional?
A: It's a sign!
B: It's a double tap on a screen.
A: But he never likes stories.
B: Okay, maybe a tiny sign. But chill.
japanese: 勘違（かんちが）いかな？／自意識（じいしき）過剰（かじょう）？
chinese: 我有幻觉吗? (Wǒ yǒu huànjué ma?) / 我在想入非非吗? (Wǒ zài xiǎngrù fēifēi ma?)
spanish: ¿Estoy alucinando? / ¿Me estoy montando una película?

example:
A: Want another shot of tequila?
B: I can't possibly, I have work at 8.
A: Just one more!
B: I'll die tomorrow. Seriously.
A: You're no fun.
B: I'm responsible. Someone has to be.
japanese: 絶対（ぜったい）無理（むり）／ありえへん
chinese: 我可办不到 (Wǒ kě bànbùdào) / 实在是不行 (Shízài shì bùxíng)
spanish: No puedo / Imposible

primary: Are you investing in shares market?
example:
A: Are you investing in the market lately?
B: Just some index funds, nothing crazy.
A: Tech stocks are blowing up.
B: Too risky for me.
A: Scared money don't make money.
B: Lost money don't pay rent.
japanese: 株（かぶ）やってる？
chinese: 你在炒股吗? (Nǐ zài chǎogǔ ma?) / 玩儿股票吗? (Wánr gǔpiào ma?)
spanish: ¿Inviertes en bolsa? / ¿Juegas a la bolsa?

example:
A: The stock market took a dive today.
B: Retail investors are panicking.
A: Volatility is through the roof.
B: Good time to buy the dip?
A: If you have cash to burn.
B: I'll sit this one out.
japanese: 株式（かぶしき）市場（しじょう）
chinese: 股市 (Gǔshì) / 证券市场 (Zhèngquàn shìchǎng)
spanish: La bolsa / El mercado de valores

similar: pull a rabbit out of a hat
example:
A: The presentation is in an hour.
B: Can we pull it off?
A: We have to. No choice.
B: I'll finish the slides, you prep speech.
A: Teamwork makes the dream work.
B: Let's do this.
japanese: やってのける／成功（せいこう）させる
chinese: 搞定 (Gǎodìng) / 拿下了 (Náxià le)
spanish: Lograrlo / Sacarlo adelante

example:
A: That burger was the best, no cap.
B: Better than Shake Shack?
A: Way better. On god.
B: That's a bold claim.
A: Go try it, you'll see.
B: Alright, I trust your taste.
japanese: マジで／ガチで（嘘（うそ）じゃない）
chinese: 真不是盖的 (Zhēn bùshì gài de) / 真的，没骗你 (Zhēnde, méi piàn nǐ)
spanish: Te lo juro / Va en serio

example:
A: I need a cheap, reliable car.
B: This Honda fits the bill.
A: It's kinda ugly though.
B: You said cheap and reliable.
A: Fair point.
B: It runs forever, just buy it.
japanese: ぴったりだ／おあつらえ向（む）きだ
chinese: 挺合适的 (Tǐng héshì de) / 正中下怀 (Zhèngzhòng xiàhuái)
spanish: Encaja perfecto / Es justo lo que buscaba

example:
A: Wanna grab a beer?
B: Can't, I'm on the clock.
A: Your boss isn't even there.
B: Doesn't matter, cameras everywhere.
A: Lame.
B: Being employed is nice though.
japanese: 勤務（きんむ）中（ちゅう）だ／仕事（しごと）中（ちゅう）だ
chinese: 我上班呢 (Wǒ shàngbān ne) / 工作时间 (Gōngzuò shíjiān)
spanish: Estoy currando / Estoy en horario de trabajo

meaning: 안개가 조금 꼈다 / (비유적으로) 머릿속이 좀 흐릿하다
example:
A: Do you remember the plan?
B: Ideally... but it's a bit foggy.
A: You drank too much last night.
B: Yeah, major brain fog today.
A: Drink some water.
B: I need an IV drip, honestly.
japanese: 記憶（きおく）が曖昧（あいまい）だ／頭（あたま）がぼんやりする
chinese: 脑子有点糊涂 (Nǎozi yǒudiǎn hútu) / 模模糊糊的 (Mómóhūhū de)
spanish: Lo tengo borroso / No me acuerdo bien

example:
A: Did you hear the storm?
B: Heard everything, I'm a light sleeper.
A: I slept like a log.
B: Lucky you. I'm exhausted.
A: Take a nap later.
B: I can never nap during the day.
japanese: 眠（ねむ）りが浅（あさ）い／すぐ目（め）が覚（さ）める
chinese: 觉轻 (Jiàoqīng) / 睡觉警醒 (Shuìjiào jǐngxǐng)
spanish: Tengo el sueño ligero / Me despierto con nada

example:
A: Why didn't you talk to him?
B: I tend to be shy around new people.
A: He was totally flirting with you.
B: I just froze up.
A: You need a wingman next time.
B: Please, help me out.
japanese: 人見知（ひとみし）りする方（ほう）だ／内気（うちき）だ
chinese: 我这人比较腼腆 (Wǒ zhè rén bǐjiào miǎntiǎn) / 我比较害羞 (Wǒ bǐjiào hàixiū)
spanish: Soy algo tímido / Me da corte

meaning: 카메라 앞에서 부끄러워하는, 사진 찍히는 걸 어색해하는
example:
A: Let's take a selfie!
B: No, I'm camera shy.
A: Just one! You look great.
B: I always look awkward.
A: I'll use a filter.
B: Fine, but don't tag me yet.
japanese: 写真（しゃしん）嫌（ぎら）い／カメラを避（さ）ける
chinese: 怕镜头 (Pà jìngtóu) / 不上相 (Bù shàngxiàng)
spanish: No me gustan las fotos / Me da vergüenza la cámara

similar: It's back to its original state.
example:
A: Did you manage to fix that cracked screen?
B: Yeah, look at it. It's as good as new.
A: Wow, I can't even see where the crack was.
B: The repair shop did a solid job. Worth every penny.
A: No cap. It looks like you just bought it.
B: For real. I'm definitely going back there if I break it again.
japanese: 新品（しんぴん）同様（どうよう）だ
chinese: 跟新的一样 (Gēn xīn de yīyàng) / 焕然一新 (Huànrán yīxīn)
spanish: Está como nuevo / Impecable

primary: They have a lot in common.
similar: They have a lot of similarities.
They're two peas in a pod.
example:
A: Have you met my new coworkers? They're hilarious.
B: Yeah, I noticed they have a lot in common. Both are into retro games.
A: Facts. They've been talking about old-school Nintendo all day.
B: It's good they hit it off so quickly.
A: For sure. Makes the office vibe a lot more chill.
B: Definitely. Team chemistry is everything.
japanese: 彼（かれ）らは似（に）たもの同士（どうし）だ／共通点（きょうつうてん）が多（おお）い
chinese: 志趣相投 (Zhìqù xiāngtóu) / 有很多共同点 (Yǒu hěnduō gòngtóngdiǎn)
spanish: Tienen mucho en común / Son tal para cual

example:
A: I decided to volunteer at the animal shelter again this weekend.
B: Haha, that's typical of you. Always trying to help out.
A: I just can't say no to those cute faces, you know?
B: I know. You've always had a big heart.
A: I guess it's just my thing.
B: It's a good thing. Don't ever change.
japanese: いかにも君（きみ）らしいね
chinese: 这很像你的风格 (Zhè hěn xiàng nǐ de fēnggé) / 真是你的作风 (Zhēnshì nǐ de zuòfēng)
spanish: Típico de ti / No podías ser otro

example:
A: I'm heading out for my trip tomorrow morning.
B: Safe travels! Make sure you look after yourself while you're away.
A: I will. I've got my vitamins and my itinerary all set.
B: Good. Don't push yourself too hard, just enjoy the vibe.
A: Thanks, fam. I'll hit you up when I land.
B: Sounds good. Peace out!
japanese: 自分（じぶん）を大切（たいせつ）にしてね／元気（げんき）でね
chinese: 多多保重 (Duōduō bǎozhòng) / 照顾好你自己 (Zhàogù hǎo nǐ zìjǐ)
spanish: Cuídate mucho / No te descuides

example:
A: I'm thinking about starting my own podcast, but I'm nervous.
B: Honestly? Go for it! You've got so many interesting stories to tell.
A: You really think people would listen?
B: 100%. Your perspective is unique, and that's what matters.
A: Alright, I'm gonna start recording this weekend.
B: That's what I'm talking about! I'll be your first listener.
japanese: やっちゃえよ！／行（い）け！
chinese: 放手去做吧! (Fàngshǒu qù zuò ba!) / 去干吧! (Qù gàn ba!)
spanish: ¡Dale! / ¡A por ello!

example:
A: Did you hear what the new manager did this morning?
B: Ugh, yeah. Honestly, he's a piece of work. Always micromanaging.
A: It's getting really old, really fast.
B: Facts. I don't know how much longer I can deal with it.
A: Hopefully he chills out once he's settled in.
B: I wouldn't hold my breath. He seems set in his ways.
japanese: 彼（かれ）は一筋縄（ひとすじなわ）ではいかない／厄介（やっかい）な人（ひと）だ
chinese: 真是个奇葩 (Zhēnshì gè qípā) / 真是个极品 (Zhēnshì gè jípǐn)
spanish: Menuda pieza / Es un personaje

example:
A: I'm trusting you with this big account. Don't mess it up.
B: I won't let you down, I promise. I've been preparing for this.
A: I know you have. I believe in your skills.
B: Thanks for the opportunity. I'm gonna give it 110%.
A: That's the energy I like to see.
B: I'll have the first draft ready by tomorrow morning.
japanese: 期待（きたい）は裏切（うらぎ）らないよ／任（まか）せて
chinese: 我不会让你失望的 (Wǒ bùhuì ràng nǐ shīvàng de) / 包在我身上 (Bāo zài wǒ shēnshàng)
spanish: No te fallaré / No te decepcionaré

primary: I've been trying to reach you.
similar: I've been trying to get ahold of you.
I've been blowing up your phone.
I've been trying to connect with you.
I was trying to find you.
example:
A: Yo, I missed like five calls from you! What's up?
B: Man, I've been trying to reach you all day! Where were you?
A: My phone was on silent during the movie. My bad.
B: All good. Anyway, we're all meeting at the pizza spot in ten.
A: Say less. I'm leaving right now.
B: Bet. See you there.
japanese: ずっと連絡（れんらく）してたんだけど／探（さが）してたよ
chinese: 我一直都在联系你 (Wǒ yīzhí dōu zài liánxì nǐ) / 找你半天了 (Zhǎo nǐ bàntiān le)
spanish: Te he estado buscando / Llevo rato llamándote

primary: It was a stroke of luck.
example:
A: How did you find such a great apartment in this market?
B: Honestly, it was a stroke of luck. I saw the listing five minutes after it went up.
A: That's insane. Most spots are gone in an hour.
B: For real. I signed the lease before anyone else even toured it.
A: You definitely used up all your luck for the year on that one.
B: Facts. But honestly? Totally worth it.
japanese: まぐれだ／運（うん）が良（よ）かっただけ
chinese: 真是走运 (Zhēnshì zǒuyùn) / 瞎猫碰上死耗子 (Xiāmāo pèngshàng sǐ hàozi)
spanish: Fue un golpe de suerte / Fue pura chiripa

example:
A: You've been really quiet lately. Is everything alright?
B: I'm just stressed, I guess. It's no big deal.
A: Look, don't bottle up your feelings. It's better to talk about it.
B: I just don't wanna bother anyone with my problems.
A: You're not bothering me. That's what friends are for.
B: Thanks. Maybe I do need to vent a little.
japanese: 溜（た）め込（こ）まないで／吐（は）き出（だ）して
chinese: 别憋在心里 (Bié biē zài xīnlǐ) / 把话说出来 (Bǎ huà shuō chūlái)
spanish: No te guardes las cosas / Desahógate

example:
A: There's pizza left?
B: Yeah, don't be shy, take some.
A: I don't want to be greedy.
B: We're gonna throw it out otherwise.
A: In that case, give me two slices.
B: That's the spirit.
japanese: 遠慮（えんりょ）しないで
chinese: 别不好意思 (Bié bù hǎoyìsi) / 别害羞 (Bié hàixiū)
spanish: No tengas vergüenza / Sin miedo

similar: I'm starting to appreciate you more.
example:
A: I know I'm a bit much sometimes, but I mean well.
B: Don't worry about it. Honestly? You're growing on me.
A: Oh, really? I thought I was annoying you.
B: You were at first, but now I think you're just hilarious.
A: I'll take that as a win.
B: As you should. Let's get some coffee.
japanese: だんだん好（す）きになってきた／良（よ）さが分（わ）かってきた
chinese: 我越来越喜欢你了 (Wǒ yuèláiyuè xǐhuan nǐ le) / 你挺招人喜欢的 (Nǐ tǐng zhāorén xǐhuan de)
spanish: Te estoy cogiendo cariño / Me estás ganando

similar: I worked late into the night.
I put in extra hours at night.
example:
A: You look exhausted. Did you actually get any sleep?
B: Barely. I burnt the midnight oil to finish that presentation.
A: Was it worth it? Hope the client liked it.
B: They loved it. All that effort really paid off.
A: Good to hear, but you should definitely crash early tonight.
B: 100%. My brain is officially fried.
japanese: 夜遅（よるおそ）くまで頑張（がんば）った
chinese: 挑灯夜战 (Tiǎodēngyèzhàn) / 熬夜苦干 (Áoyè kǔgàn)
spanish: Me quedé trabajando hasta tarde / Trasnoché trabajando

example:
A: What was your lap time?
B: Shy of two minutes.
A: That's a new personal best!
B: I wanted to break 1:50 though.
A: You're getting faster.
B: Next time, I got this.
japanese: 2分（ふん）弱（じゃく）／2分（ふん）切（き）るくらい
chinese: 差两分钟 (Chà liǎng fēnzhōng) / 不到两分钟 (Bù dào liǎng fēnzhōng)
spanish: Menos de dos minutos / Casi dos minutos

primary: That would be the best case scenario.
similar: If everything goes right, that's what happens.
example:
A: If we launch by Monday, we'll beat all our competitors.
B: That would be the best case scenario. Everyone's working overtime.
A: Do you think we can actually make it happen?
B: It's a tight squeeze, but it's definitely possible.
A: Fingers crossed. This would be huge for the team.
B: For real. Let's just keep this momentum going.
japanese: それが一番（いちばん）いい形（かたち）だね／理想（りそう）的（てき）だね
chinese: 那是理想情况 (Nà shì lǐxiǎng qíngkuàng) / 最完美的打算 (Zuì wánměi de dǎsuàn)
spanish: Sería lo ideal / En el mejor de los casos
